page.title: Official film and television co-production in Australia

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.4)
revision.text:
An [[international co-production|international film or television co-production]] is a production made by production companies in different countries. This note focuses on ‘official’ Australian co-productions, that is, co-productions that meet the requirements for benefits under the [http://www.afc.gov.au/filminginaustralia/copros/fiapage_2.aspx Australian Official Co-Production Program]. It looks at trends in production, the potential impact of recent changes to film funding, and what lies ahead for Australia’s involvement in co-production.
==Official co-production in Australia==
Official co-productions are made possible by formal agreements between countries. For filmmakers, the key attraction of a treaty co-production is that it qualifies as a national production in each of the partner nations. Thus, it can access benefits that are available to the local film and television industry in more than one country. Benefits may include government subsidies, tax concessions and inclusion in domestic television broadcast quotas.
The Australian government has signed official film co-production agreements with the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Italy]], [[Ireland]], [[Israel]], [[Germany]], [[China]] and, most recently, [[Singapore]] (as treaties); and [[France]] and [[New Zealand]] (as memoranda of understanding or MOUs.<ref>AFC (Australian Film Commission). 2007. [http://www.afc.gov.au/downloads/pubs/copreport_jun07_dec07.pdf 'Data on Official Coproductions'] and [http://www.afc.gov.au/filminginaustralia/copros/copro_update/fiapage_87.aspx 'Coproduction Update'.]</ref> Official co-production agreements set the criteria that a production must meet in order to be considered an official co-production. Criteria may cover co-financing, creative participation and copyright ownership.
[[International co-production]]s also occur outside the framework of official co-productions, either with countries that do not have an agreement with Australia, or as projects that do not satisfy official co-production criteria. Examples of the former include the Australia/US co-productions ''[[Crocodile Dundee in Los Angeles]]'' (2001) and ''[[Farscape]]'' (1999–2003).
Australian co-production agreements are administered by the [https://web.archive.org/web/20071111165204/http://afc.gov.au/ Australian Film Commission] (AFC) on behalf of the [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]]. (In July 2008 the AFC will be merged with other film agencies to become [[Screen Australia]]; the new organisation will then have oversight over co-productions.) The overriding objective is to maintain an overall balance between the creative and financial contributions of each country over time. Accordingly, there is some discretion in granting co-production status to an individual co-production if there is an imbalance between financial and creative contributions.
The AFC’s [http://www.afc.gov.au/filminginaustralia/copros/guide_app/fiapage_63.aspx International Co-production Program Guidelines] set out eligibility conditions for the granting of co-production status. These relate to the authorship of the underlying works and screenplays, co-producer participation, sources of finance, control over copyright; and the engagement of key creative participants. Co-productions are restricted to particular genres: feature films, drama series, miniseries, documentaries and telemovies. At the level of the individual production there must be a producer from each of the partner countries, a minimum level of Australian equity in the project (20 to 30 per cent) and matching participation by Australian creative components.
A points system is used to ensure a balance between the Australian budget contribution and the participation of key personnel (creative and crew). Points are attached to key creative positions including director, writer, editor and key cast. By amassing a minimum number of points, a production can qualify as ‘Australian’. In this context the participation of Australian financial and creative resources acts as a proxy for ‘Australian content’. Different points systems apply to the production of live action drama, documentary and animation, reflecting the importance of particular roles specific to each genre.
==Australia’s engagement in international co-productions==
Australia was a relatively late entrant into the sphere of official co-production. Its first agreement was signed with France in 1986. France itself entered into a co-production agreement with Italy in 1949 while Canada, a leading co-production country, entered its first agreement in 1963 and now has agreements with 53 other countries.
As of April 2007, Australia had engaged in 96 official co-productions that were either completed or in production. Feature films and television drama are the production types most likely to be co-productions: they total 35 and 21 productions respectively, with total budgeted costs of A$385.15 million and A$294.71 million. Australia has partnered most frequently with Canada and the United Kingdom. Australia and Canada have produced 31 co-productions with budgets totalling A$347 million and Australia and the United Kingdom have co-produced 30 productions, with budgets of A$323.43 million.<ref name="Get the Picture">AFC (Australian Film Commission). 2007. [http://www.afc.gov.au/gtp Get the Picture.]</ref>
Australia’s official co-production record is modest by international standards. In 2005–2006 Australia engaged in 10 co-productions with total budgets of $60 million and an Australian spend of $35m.<ref name="Get the Picture"/> Canada, by comparison, had 58 co-productions in 2006 with total budgets in excess of C$404 million and a Canadian share of C$166 million.<ref>Telefilm Canada. 2006. [http://www.telefilm.gc.ca/04/42.asp Statistics on Coproduction 2006.]</ref> In the same year, the United Kingdom had 57 productions with total budgets of ₤124.8 million.<ref>UK Film Council 2006. [http://www.ukfilmcouncil.org.uk/yearbook Statistical Yearbook 2006/07]</ref>
Further, co-productions represent a small proportion of the Australian industry. In 2005–2006, 32 feature films were made in Australia. Of these, four were foreign and only three were co-productions. Domestic expenditure for local films was A$97 million and for foreign films was A$23 million, while co-productions totalled a modest A$13 million. Similarly, local television drama in the six years to 2005–2006 had an average annual spend of A$202 million, while foreign drama and co-productions amounted to A$37 million apiece.
Although co-productions contributed only a small proportion of total production budgets in Australia, individual co-productions tend to have higher budgets. Of the 35 co-produced feature films, 49 per cent had budgets in excess of $10m. By comparison, only 18% of all Australian-produced features between 1988/89 and 2005/06 reached this level. Mini-series showed a similar bias: 90% of co-productions had budgets between $6 and $20m compared with just 61% of all series over the same period.<ref name="Get the Picture"/>
Co-production is a more common production mode for children’s television drama. In the six years to 2005/06, the Australian industry averaged 96 hours of co-produced TV drama, at budgets of $61.8m. Of this, 27 hours were dedicated to children’s drama, at average annual budgets of $16.1m. The higher reliance on co-production for children’s content stems from the difficulty of financing children’s programs, and the ability of children’s animation to translate easily into different cultures.
While the trend through the 1990s was for a greater total spend in Australia for co-productions, reaching a high of $111m in 2001/2002, the trend since then has been downward, with only $36m being spent in 2005/06. This is largely due to a fall in television drama co-production from a high of $83m in 2001/02 to just $23m in 2005/06. Feature films, on the other hand, have experienced a revival from 2000/01, but have only averaged a modest $22.2m in Australian spend in the six years from 2001/02.
==The future of co-production in Australia==
A number of economic, industry and cultural factors influence decisions to undertake an official co-production. These factors include the value of the Australian dollar, the availability of skilled crews, access to tax offsets and other financial incentives, the generation of creative content and the signing of further bilateral agreements. Higher production budgets, falling television licence fees and lower distribution guarantees are all factors that will continue to drive the international demand for co-productions. As discussed by Hoskins, McFadyen, & Finn, Australian producers find financial pooling the most important benefit of co-production and it is likely that this will be pursued more vigorously in the future.
The recently introduced [[Film and television financing in Australia|Producer Offset]] is also expected to drive a higher level of co-production. Australian production companies making official co-productions will be automatically entitled to a tax offset of 40% of qualifying Australian production expenditure (QAPE) for feature films and 20% of QAPE for documentary, television series, telemovies and short animation.
An increase in the number of countries with which Australia has co-production agreements may also encourage greater levels of co-production. Australia recently entered into agreements with [[China]] and [[Singapore]], increasing the number of agreements to 11. Further, [[Australia]] has signed agreements with a number of [[Europe]]an countries which are parties to the European Convention on Cinematographic Co-production. Indirectly, this convention may provide further opportunities for collaboration with other [[European Union]] countries.
Noting the favourable performance results for Australian co-productions, Hoskins, McFadyen and Finn advocate 'greater government initiative in treaty negotiation and increased official openness to international co-production'.<ref>Hoskins, Colin, Stuart McFadyen and Adam Finn. 1999. [http://www.cjc-online.ca/viewarticle.php?id=508 “International Joint Ventures in the Production of Australian Feature Films and Television Programs.”] ''Canadian Journal of Communication'' 24(1).</ref> As the Australian film financing landscape shifts over the coming period, there is every chance that these policy issues will provide the grist for further discussions. At the same time, we can expect that Australian producers and their international partners will seek out innovative ways to harness the benefits of co-production, particularly in light of the new tax regime.<ref>In fact, some have suggested that tax incentives are a principal driver of the worldwide upswing in coproduction activity. See Norbert Morawetz, Jane Hardy, Colin Haslam and Keith Randle, 2007, 'Finance, Policy and Industrial Dynamics – The Rise of Coproductions in the Film Industry', ''Industry and Innovation'' 14(4): 421–443.</ref>

'''Pierre Bec''' (in [[Occitan]] '''''Pèire Bèc''''' 11 December 1921 – 30 June 2014)<ref>{{cite web|title=Mor l'occitanista Pèire Bèc|url=http://www20.gencat.cat/portal/site/Llengcat/menuitem.21576464db9e81e7a129d410b0c0e1a0/?vgnextoid=035748a344371110VgnVCM1000000b0c1e0aRCRD&vgnextchannel=035748a344371110VgnVCM1000000b0c1e0aRCRD&vgnextfmt=detall&contentid=f6ec57aa141f6410VgnVCM1000008d0c1e0aRCRD|publisher=www20.gencat.cat|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref> was a [[French people|French]] [[Occitan language]] poet and linguist. Born in [[Paris]], he spent his childhood in [[Comminges]], where he learnt [[Occitan]]. He was deported to [[Germany]] between 1943 and 1945. After returning, he studied in Paris, where he graduated in 1959. He was one of the founders of the IEO or [[Institut d'Estudis Occitans]] (Institute of Occitan Studies) as well as its president from 1962 to 1980.
==Life== Bec was titular professor at [[Poitiers]] university and assistant director of the ''Centre d'Études Supérieures de Civilisation Médiévale'' (Centre for high studies in medieval civilisation).<ref>{{cite news | last = Covell| first = Roger| coauthors = | title = Poets' justice; CD Reviews | work = | pages = | publisher = [[Sydney Morning Herald]]| date = October 20, 2001}}</ref> He is considered one of the most important specialists in Occitan [[dialectology]] and in mediaeval Occitan literature. His activity is distributed among Occitanist politics, philological research and literary creation. He collaborated with publications like ''Cahiers de Civilisation Médiévale'', ''Revue de Linguistique Romane'', ''Estudis Romànics'', ''Oc''.
In 1982 he took part in the Linguistic Normalisation commission for [[Aranese]], with [[Jacme Taupiac]] and [[Miquèu Grosclaude]]: they established some linguistics norms, officialised in 1983, following [[Institut d'Estudis Occitans|IEO]]'s indications for [[Gascon language|Gascon]].
Bec died in [[Poitiers]] on 30 June 2014, at the age of 92.<ref>[http://www20.gencat.cat/portal/site/Llengcat/menuitem.21576464db9e81e7a129d410b0c0e1a0/?vgnextoid=035748a344371110VgnVCM1000000b0c1e0aRCRD&vgnextchannel=035748a344371110VgnVCM1000000b0c1e0aRCRD&vgnextfmt=detall&contentid=f6ec57aa141f6410VgnVCM1000008d0c1e0aRCRD Mor l'occitanista Pèire Bèc]</ref>
== Importance for Gallo-Cisalpine language(s) == As a linguist, Pierre Bec stated, within his ''Manuel pratique de Philologie romane'' (2nd volume, p. 316) that some kind of diachronical unity holds between [[Rhaeto-Romance]] languages (i.e. [[Romansh language|Romansh]], [[Friulian language|Friulian]] and [[Ladin language|Ladin]]) and [[Northern Italian]] or Cisalpine ones ([[Western Lombard language|Western Lombard]], [[Eastern Lombard language|Eastern Lombard]], [[Piedmontese language|Piedmontese]], [[Venetian language|Venetan]], [[Emiliano-Romagnolo language|Emiliano-Romagnolo]] and [[Ligurian language (Romance)|Ligurian]]). This issue has been further investigated by the [[Australian]] linguist [[Geoffrey Hull]].<ref>Hull, Geoffrey, PhD thesis 1982 (University of Sydney), published as ''The Linguistic Unity of Northern Italy and Rhaetia: Historical Grammar of the Padanian Language.'' 2 vols. Sydney: Beta Crucis, 2017.</ref>
== Works ==
===Literature===
* ''Petite anthologie de la lyrique occitane du Moyen Âge'' (1954) * ''Les saluts d'amour du troubadour Arnaud de Mareuil'' (1961) * ''La langue occitane'' (1963)<ref>{{cite news | last = Smith| first = Alex Duval| coauthors = | title = Europe: The tongue of the troubadours lives on - Babel| work = | pages = | publisher = The Guardian| date = July 26, 1991}}</ref> * ''Manuel pratique de Philologie romane'' (1970–1971) * ''Burlesque et obscénité chez les troubadours'' (1984) * ''Chants d'amour des femmes troubadours'' (1995) * ''Au briu de l'estona'' (1955) poesia * ''Sonets barròcs entà Iseut'' (1979) poesia * ''Lo hiu tibat'' (1978) novel·la * ''Sebastian'' (1980) novel·la * ''Raconte d’una mort tranquilla'' (1993) narració * ''Contes de l'unic'' (1977) narració
===Linguistics=== * ''Manuel pratique d'occitan moderne'' (Picard, 1973; 2e édition 1983) * ''Manuel pratique de philologie romane'' (Picard, 1970 (vol. 1), 1971 (vol. 2) - reedit. 2000) * ''Les Interférences linguistiques entre gascon et languedocien dans les parlers du Comminges et du Couserans'' (PUF, 1968): Essai d'aréologie systématique.

{{good article}} [[File:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|thumb|The [[Flag of the United Kingdom]] |256x256px]]
'''Plastic Brit''', or '''Plastic Briton''',<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Chadband |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/athletics/9136588/World-Indoor-Athletics-Championships-Plastic-Briton-Yamile-Aldama-proud-to-win-gold-for-Great-Britain.html |title='Plastic Briton' Yamile Aldama proud to win gold for Great Britain |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 11 March 2012|accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> is a pejorative term used to describe athletes who choose to represent [[Great Britain Olympic Team|Great Britain]] in international sport despite having personal connections to another country.<ref>{{cite news|first=Martin|last= Samuel |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-2024259/Martin-Samuel-So-Yamille-Aldama-plastic-Brit-outlawed.html |title=Martin Samuel: So, Yamille Aldama is another plastic Brit who should be outlawed |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> Some media critics believe it undermines the purpose of international sport for the purpose of medals.<ref>{{cite news|first=Laurie |last=Whitwell |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2174623/Frankie-Fredericks-Plastic-Brit-debate.html |title=Frankie Fredericks on Plastic Brit debate |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=6 July 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first1=Andrew|last1= Blenkinsop |first2= David|last2= Kinross |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/olympic_infographics_and_data/9391327/Team-GB-Plastic-Brits-where-do-they-come-from.html |title=Team GB: 'Plastic Brits' - where do they come from? |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 11 July 2012|accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> The term came into popular use in 2012 when it was reported that 61 out of 542 (11%) of the [[Great Britain at the 2012 Summer Olympics|British Olympic team]] had been born abroad.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2171923/London-2012-Games-Team-GB-61-plastic-Brits.html |title=Team GB have 61 'plastic Brits' |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref>
==History and use== The term "Plastic Brit" is derived from [[Plastic Paddy]], which is used to describe people who claim to be Irish despite not residing in that country.<ref name= tele /> While the concept gained the British media's attention in the run-up to the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], it had also been used in describing members of other British sporting teams. England's cricket team had a perceived problem of having too many foreign-born players.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/features/5813538/crickets-foreign-legion/|title=London Cricket's foreign legions |publisher=The Spectator |date=3 March 2010 |accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref> The [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] responded to the issue by lengthening the residency period before a foreign player can be accepted to play for England to seven years.<ref>{{cite news|author=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/30/ecb-england-overseas-qualification-period |title=ECB extends qualification period for overseas players to seven years |newspaper=The Guardian |date=30 April 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012}}</ref>
The term was popularised in the United Kingdom through its usage in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' newspaper to describe athletes born outside the UK who had been selected to represent Great Britain at the [[London 2012 Summer Olympics]].<ref name=point>{{cite news|first=Sunder |last=Katwala |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/aug/03/plastic-brits-olympic-team |title=Accusing Olympic athletes of being 'plastic Brits' misses the point |newspaper=The Guardian |date=3 August 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> The term originally had foundations from [[South Africa]]n-born [[Zola Budd]] having her British citizenship application fast tracked in order to represent Great Britain at the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=mirror/>
Several athletes have been described by the press as "Plastic Brits". [[Tiffany Porter]] was selected as the captain of Great Britain's athletics team at the [[2012 IAAF World Indoor Championships]] despite being born in the [[United States]]. She was described as a "Plastic Brit" in the media for refusing to recite the words of the British national anthem, "[[God Save the Queen]]", at a press conference.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last= McEvoy |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2112352/Tiffany-Porter-lead-Team-GB-World-Indoor-Championships.html |title=It could have been Farah or Ennis but our athletes will be led by a Plastic Brit|newspaper=Daily Mail |date=8 March 2012|accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> After Porter broke the British record for the [[100 metres hurdles]], the previous record holder [[Angela Thorp]] said that she felt "devastated" that Porter had broken her record because she had expected [[Jessica Ennis]] to break it.<ref>{{cite news|first=Martin|last= Samuel |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-2008394/Martin-Samuel-Losing-record-Plastic-Brit-left-devastated.html |title=Losing my record to a Plastic Brit has left me devastated|newspaper=Daily Mail |date=11 June 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2013}}</ref>
The term was used to describe a number of [[amateur wrestling|amateur wrestlers]] such as [[Myroslav Dykun]] and [[Yana Stadnik]] who had not been born in the UK and had been given [[British citizenship]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Jonathan |last=McEvoy |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2109533/London-2012-Olympics-No-passports-plastic-Brits-wrestlers.html |title=No passports for plastic Brits wrestlers |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=2 March 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Jonathan |last=McEvoy |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-2151901/BOA-gives-Plastic-Brit-wrestler-Myroslav-Dykun-push-Games.html |title=Kicked out! BOA give 'Plastic Brit' wrestlers the push from Games|newspaper=Daily Mail |date=30 March 2012 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref> Only one wrestler had competed for Great Britain at the 2012 Olympics, [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]]-born [[Olga Butkevych]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Nick|first=Hope|title=London 2012: Ukraine-born Olga Butkevych may wrestle for GB|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/18258740|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 April 2013|date=30 May 2012}}</ref> British Wrestling had the majority of its host nation berths removed by the [[British Olympic Association]] because of British Wrestling's failing to reach set performance targets.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hope |first=Nick |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/18253302 |title=British Wrestling has Olympic places cut |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 May 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> The term "Plastic Brit" was also used when there were calls for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]'s Spanish goalkeeper [[Manuel Almunia]] to play for the [[England national football team]] in 2009.<ref name=tele>{{cite news|first=Jim|last=White|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/international/england/8682674/As-Manu-Tuilagi-prepares-for-England-debut-perhaps-it-is-flattering-to-be-seen-as-foreigners-sporting-haven.html |title=As Manu Tuilagi prepares for England debut, perhaps it is flattering to be seen as foreigners' sporting haven |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 5 August 2011 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref>
It was argued by some newspaper reporters that selecting athletes born outside of the UK was discriminatory against British-born athletes and was against the spirit of the Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|author=Reuters |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-08-09/news/sns-rt-oly-wres-wrw55k-rounds-day13briton-pixl6e8j19un-20120809_1_british-passport-wrestler-homegrown-athletes |title="Plastic Brit" out after six minutes at Games |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=9 August 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> In 2012, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) imposed a mandatory three-year waiting period before athletes could compete in the Olympics for another country.<ref name="Magnay/Telegraph">{{cite news| first= Jacquelin |last=Magnay| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/news/9143611/London-2012-Olympics-IOC-President-Jacques-Rogge-hits-out-at-mercenary-athletes.html |title=IOC President Jacques Rogge hits out at mercenary athletes |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> In response, [[International Olympic Committee]] chairman [[Jacques Rogge]] said, "Then there are cases where there is support [for athletes competing for other countries] but they go because there is a bigger gain [for the athlete] in another country. Legally we can't stop it but it doesn't mean we love it."<ref name="Magnay/Telegraph" /> In 2015, the term was also erroneously levelled at sprinter [[Zharnel Hughes]] by some newspapers despite Hughes having British citizenship by virtue of being born in [[Anguilla]], a [[British Overseas Territory]] without IOC recognition.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/jul/03/zharnel-hughes-plastic-brit-shrugs-off-british-championships</ref>
== Criticism == The term "Plastic Brit" has been criticised in the British media. The ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' suggested that fans overlook athletes' places of birth if they perform well for Great Britain.<ref name=tele /> ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper criticised the ''Daily Mail''{{'}}s usage of the term, saying that the definition of a "Plastic Brit" was inconsistent and that under some definitions, some British-born athletes such as [[Ryan Giggs]] would be classed as "Plastic Brits" for failing to sing "God Save the Queen".<ref name=point /> The ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' newspaper also said that the ''Daily Mail'', along with other newspapers, had supported the selection of Zola Budd to represent Great Britain at the 1984 Olympic Games.<ref name=mirror>{{cite news|first=Steve |last=Ovett |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/athletics/steve-ovett-plastic-brits-is-a-snide-1202277 |title=Plastic Brits is a snide term but why make Tiffany Porter sing the national anthem |newspaper=Daily Mirror |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' newspaper said that a third of Great Britain's gold medal winners at the Olympics and Paralympic games had a non-British parent or had been born outside of the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Riding |first=Matthew |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/news/plastic-brits-they-were-the-secret-of-our-success-8038764.html |title=Plastic Brits? They were the secret of our success |newspaper=The Independent |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref>
A number of athletes were also critical of the term. Triple jumper [[Yamilé Aldama]], who had been described as a "Plastic Brit", openly criticised the term in an article in ''The Guardian'' newspaper. She said, "I have lived in this country for 11 years, I am married to a British man, I have British children, I train under a British coach, at a British club. This is my home. What are they talking about?".<ref name="Aldama/Guardian" /> She also said that a number of other athletes, including Farah and [[Kevin Pietersen]]{{mdash}}who had represented Great Britain and the [[England cricket team]] respectively{{mdash}}had not been born in the United Kingdom but were not branded as "Plastic Brits".<ref name="Aldama/Guardian">{{cite news|first=Yamilé |last=Aldama |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2012/jul/14/yamile-aldama-plastic-brit-jibe-offensive |title=Yamilé Aldama: Plastic Brit jibe is so offensive in our country today |newspaper=The Guardian |date= 14 July 2012|accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> Marathon runner [[Paula Radcliffe]] also criticised the term, asking for Great Britain supporters at the Olympics to support every athlete representing Great Britain, regardless of their countries of origin.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/17624597 |title=London 2012: Paula Radcliffe gives support to 'Plastic Brits' |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 April 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> Long-distance runner [[Mo Farah]], when asked by a journalist if he should run for [[Somalia]], said, "Look mate, this is my country. This is where I grew up, this is where I started life. This is my country and when I put on my Great Britain vest I'm proud. I'm very proud."<ref>{{cite news|last=Eaton |first=George |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/politics/2012/08/how-mo-farah-rejected-plastic-brit-charge |title=How Mo Farah rejected the "plastic Brit" charge |newspaper=New Statesman |date=5 August 2012 |accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> [[Fiji]]an-born Paralympic discus thrower [[Derek Derenalagi]] said in the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' that he was a "Titanium Brit" after he lost his legs in an explosion while serving with the [[British Army]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Matt|last= Majendie |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/olympics/paralympics/move-over-you-plastic-brits-here-comes-the-titanium-brit-8075810.html |title=Move over you plastic Brits, here comes the 'titanium Brit' |newspaper=Evening Standard |date=23 August 2012 |accessdate=21 April 2013}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2011}} [[Image:Pigrunt.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Litters of piglets often include a runt]] In a group of animals (usually a [[Litter (animal)|litter]] of animals born in multiple births), a '''runt''' is a member which is smaller or weaker than the others.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://cancerweb.ncl.ac.uk/cgi-bin/omd?runt | title = Cancer | contribution = Runt | publisher = NCL | place = UK}}.</ref> Owing to its small size, a runt in a litter faces obvious disadvantage, including difficulties in competing with its siblings for survival and possible rejection by its mother. Therefore, in the wild, a runt is less likely to survive [[infancy]].
Even among [[domestic animals]], runts often face rejection. They may be placed under the direct care of an experienced animal breeder, although the animal's size and weakness coupled with the lack of natural parental care make this difficult. Some tamed animals are the result of reared runts.
==In popular culture== ===Runts=== * [[Wilbur (Charlotte's Web)|Wilbur]], the pig from ''[[Charlotte's Web]]'', is the runt of his litter. * Orson, the pig in Jim Davis' [[U.S. Acres|''U.S. Acres'']] is a runt who was bullied by his normal siblings. The strip changed direction when he was moved to a different farm and settled in with a supporting cast of oddball animals. * Shade the bat from ''[[Silverwing (novel)|Silverwing]]'' is a runt. * Fiver from ''[[Watership Down]]'' is a runt. * [[Clifford the Big Red Dog]] was born a runt, but inexplicably began to grow explosively until he became 25 feet tall. The narratives of many Clifford stories work on the advantages and disadvantages of his colossal size. * [[Goliath II]], in the Disney film of the same name, was a runt elephant. Hardly bigger than a mouse, he was an embarrassment to his father, Goliath I, who was a giant, and resented by the other elephants of the pack who had to avoid stepping on him. He redeemed himself when he proved to be unafraid of a mouse. *[[Ruth (dragon)|Ruth]], the hero [[Dragons (Pern)|Pernese dragon]]net from [[Anne McCaffrey]]'s novel [[the White Dragon (novel)|''The White Dragon'']], is a runt whose egg is smaller and has a harder shell than all others in the clutch. He would have died save for the intervention of young [[Jaxom]]. * [[Jock of the Bushveld|Jock]] was the runt of a litter of Staffordshire Bull Terriers who was saved from drowning by [[Sir Percy Fitzpatrick]], who later wrote about his life with the dog in [[Jock of the Bushveld]]. * [[Cadpig]], a female Dalmatian puppy in Dodie Smith's children's novel ''[[The Hundred and One Dalmatians]]'', is the runt of her litter. Thought at first to be [[stillbirth|stillborn]], she is revived by Mr. Dearly. (In the [[One Hundred and One Dalmatians|animated Disney film]], the scene where she is revived is kept, but she is otherwise unnamed. And in the [[101 Dalmatians (1996 film)|live-action Disney film]], Cadpig is still a female aptly named "Two-Tone". [[101 Dalmatians: The Series|The animated television series]], however, does include Cadpig, though she is a separate character from Lucky. * [[The Sheep-Pig|Babe]], the eponymous piglet hero of [[Dick King-Smith]]'s book (and the popular [[Babe (film)|film]] based on the novel), is a runt. In fact, he was chosen for the competition at which Farmer Hoggett won him essentially ''because'' he was a runt - his runt status therefore saving his life and shaping his destiny. * Scourge from the ''[[Warriors (novel series)|Warriors]]'' book series was a runt. * The title character from the novel ''[[Runt (novel)|Runt]]'', as the name implies, is the smallest of his wolf litter. *The [[dire wolf]] Ghost in the ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' book series was the runt of his litter of six pups, as well as an [[albino]]. He later grows to become the biggest of the six. *[[Seabiscuit]], a famous race horse, was a runt who triumphed over larger horses. Seabiscuit's story is chronicled in an eponymous book, and a movie based on that book. *Little Ann from ''[[Where The Red Fern Grows]]'' was the runt of her litter as well. * Runt, an omega wolf from ''[[Alpha and Omega (film)|Alpha and Omega]]'' series, is a runt among his pack and family. *Daggie Dogfoot from [[Pigs Might Fly]] by [[Dick King-Smith|Dick King Smith]] was the runt of his litter, and it was because he was born a runt he was taken away and came back. He later learns to swim and then saves his pig herd from a flood. *Patchi, the main character from [[Walking with Dinosaurs (film)]], is the runt of his pachyrhinosaurs litter. *Arlo, the main character from ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]'', is the runt of his siblings, but born from a big egg. *Rex, the title character of ''[[Rex the Runt]]'', is a runt *Chief. the main character from [[Wes Anderson|Wes Anderson's]] "[[Isle of Dogs (film)|Isle of Dogs]]" is the runt of his litter. *[[List of BoJack Horseman characters|Mr. Peanutbutter]], one of the main characters from [[BoJack Horseman|Bojack Horseman]], is one of the runts from his litter. Captain Peanutbutter tells Mr. Peanutbutter that he is his favourite runt of the litter.
===Runt as a name=== * An early career moniker (ca. 1970) for [[Todd Rundgren]], his band, and the title of his/their eponymously named first album, all three.
==See also== * [[Vanishing twin]]

There are at least two translations of the [[Tirukkural]] available in the [[Polish language]]. ==History of translations== The first Polish translation of the Kural text was made in prose in 1958 by Wanda Dynowska, published by the Indo-Polish Library (Biblioteka Polsko-Indyjska). During the same year, a parallel edition by the same translator appeared in [[Poland]].{{cite book | last = Sanjeevi | first = N. | author-link = | title = ''Bibliography on Tirukkural''. ''In'' First All India Tirukkural Seminar Papers | publisher = University of Madras | series = | volume = | edition = | date = 1973 | location = Chennai | pages = 147 | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }} A verse translation was made by Bohdan Gębarski, published in 1977 under the title ''Tirukkural. Święta księga południowych Indii''. It was published again in 1998.{{cite web | url = http://wysylkowa.com/ks414573.html | title = Tirukkural. Święta księga południowych Indii | last = Gębarski | first = Bohdan | date = 1977 | website = | publisher = | access-date = 14 April 2017 | quote = }}{{cite web | url = http://www.geocities.ws/nvkashraf/kur-trans/Pol-Int.htm | title = Tirukkural. Święta księga południowych Indii | last = Ashraf | first = N. V. K. | date = 1998 | website = GeoCities | publisher = | access-date = 14 April 2017 | quote = }} ==Translations== {| class="wikitable" |- !style="text-align:center; width:25%;" rowspan="2"|Translation !colspan="2"|Chapter 26, O Mięsożerstwie |- !''Kural'' 254 (Couplet 26:4) !''Kural'' 258 (Couplet 26:8) |- | style="text-align:center;"|''Bohdan Gębarski, 1977''||Wiele człowiek ma cech drapieżnego zwierzęcia,
Przecież ubój to też mordowanie. ||Niech więc śmierć ta przedwcześnie zwierzęciu zadana
Nie obciąża twojego sumienia. |} ==See also== * [[Tirukkural translations]] * [[List of Tirukkural translations by language]] == Notes == {{Portal bar|Tamil Nadu|Tamil People|Tamil civilization|Dravidian civilizations|India|Poland|Ethics|Philosophy|Literature|Poetry}} {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Gębarski, B. (1998). ''Tirukkural. Święta księga południowych Indii''. Europa. Pp. 152. {{ISBN|83-85336-54-0}}. Available from http://wysylkowa.com/ks414573.html {{Tirukkural|state=collapsed}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} [[Category:Tirukkural translations by language|Polish]]

revision.text:
In theatre, '''''les trois coups''''' (the three blows) are hit on the floor of the stage with a stick called ''brigadier'', just before the start of a performance, in order to attract public attention for the rise of [[Front curtain|the curtain]].
This tradition, especially in France, may come from the Middle Ages, where three blows, symbolizing the [[Trinity]], ended the [[Mystery play|mystery]]. These three blows could be preceded by eleven hammered ones (the twelve Apostles minus [[Judas Iscariot|Judas]]). They may also be a tribute to the nine muses of ancient Greece. Hence, there would be nine rapid blows plus the "trois coups", thus twelve blows. Twelve, being a perfect number in its symbolism, symbolized the unity of theatre.
Another explanation matches the three blows with the three bows that comedians performed before playing in front of the Court: the first one to the contender ({{Interlanguage link multi|Côté cour et côté jardin|fr|3=Côté cour et côté jardin|lt=côté jardin}}, left), the second one to the machinist ({{lang|fr|côté cour}}, right), and the third to the audience.
In [[Theatre of France#17th-century classicism|French classical theatre]], the [[dramaturge]] pounded the ground with twelve quick blows to announce to the machinists the start of the performance. Then a first blow came in response from the [[fly system]] operators; a second response rose from below the stage and a third one came from the opposite wing. Each machinist being in their position for the performance, the dramaturge could open the curtain.<ref>Jean-Paul Gousset, technical director of the [[Royal Opera of Versailles]], in ''Secrets d'histoire : Marie-Antoinette intime…'', Société européenne de production, 2010.</ref>
The military rank of ''brigadier'' was given to a worker leading a team. The [[dramaturge]], using a stick to hit the three blows, gathered the theatre staff to begin the show, like a [[brigadier]] gathering his men. Through [[metonymy]], the stick itself was called a "brigadier".
The theatre brigadier is traditionally made of wood with a piece of theatre pole{{definition needed|date=August 2016}}, decorated with red velvet and gold studded nails.
For years the [[Comédie-Française]] would hit six blows in order to commemorate the uniting of the two troupes, that of the [[Hôtel de Bourgogne (theatre)|Hôtel de Bourgogne]] and [[Molière's company]], previously associated with that of the [[Théâtre du Marais]] under [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]], allowing for daily performances.
